text: LAURENCE EAVES: Right.

Well, I was born on May, which
is the fifth month, and on the
13th day of May.

Mathematically, that's vaguely
interesting because these are
both Pythagorean primes.
Right, OK.

Well, if we look at 5, then
we can write 5 as
the sum of two squares.

So 1 squared plus 2 squared
is equal to 5.
Now if we take 13--

see if we can work
that one out.

Well, 13 is 9 plus 4, so
4 is just 2 squared.
And 3 squared is 9.
So that gives me--
now, the next one, 17.

We can do that as well, because
17 is 4 squared plus 1

squared, which is another
Pythagorean prime.
Pythagorean--

we've all heard of Pythagoras,
who was a very famous
mathematician.

So why do these numbers
bear his name?

Well, if we remember our
right-angle triangle.

So we've got a right triangle
there, and there's the
hypotenuse.

And Pythagoras tells us that if
this thing is of length A,

and this bit here is of length
B, then A squared plus B
squared equals C squared.
That's Pythagoras's Theorem.

Now, of course, A and B don't
have to be integers.

And C doesn't have
to be an integer.
They could be any number.
This could be 3.2 inches.
This could be 5.75 inches--
whatever C is then.

But we can play this
game with integers.

And when we do, we generate
these Pythagorean primes.

If we look at 13, then it turns
out all of these numbers
can be written as 4n plus 1.

So 13 is equal to 4n plus 1,
where n is equal to 3.

If we take 17, then 17 is 4n
plus 1 where n is equal to 4.

So the Pythagorean
primes have this.

We generate them this way,
but they've also got this
interesting property.

BRADY HARAN: Can I put any n in
there to get a Pythagorean

prime, or only certain
n's will do it?
LAURENCE EAVES: No, no.

For example, if we just take the
next one in this series,

if we put n equals 5, then
n equals 5 gives
me, of course, 21.
OK, so that's just 20 plus 1.

And although 21 is an odd
number, it's not a prime

number because it's equal
to 7 times 3.
So 21 is not a prime.

It's not even a prime,
so it's obviously not
a Pythagorean prime.

So it's not all values of n
that give me these, just
special values.

BRADY HARAN: We mentioned at the
start that your birthday

is the 13th of the
5th, and they're
both Pythagorean primes.
LAURENCE EAVES: Yes.

BRADY HARAN: Can you remember at
what point in your life you

realized your birthday was
two Pythagorean primes?

LAURENCE EAVES: When you asked
me to talk about numbers.

I have a really favorite
Pythagorean prime, which I'd
like to tell you about.

And then I just realized
that 13 and 5 are
two nice, small ones.

BRADY HARAN: OK, tell me about
your favorite one.

LAURENCE EAVES: Well,
my favorite one,
of course, is 137.

BRADY HARAN: For anyone that
doesn't know, by the way,

Professor Eaves is obsessed
with the number 137.

And you will see him talking
about it in multiple videos.

LAURENCE EAVES: Not really
that obsessed.

But anyway, the inverse
fine-structure constant, which

we use a lot in atomic physics
and any problems to do with

the electrons and their
quantum behavior.

The fine-structure constant
alpha-- its
inverse is almost 137.
Not exactly 137.

And lo and behold, 137 is a nice
Pythagorean prime, which
I think is quite nice.

And if we work that one out, of
course, we see-- how can we
make it up?

Well, with a little bit of
thinking, we can see that 11
squared gives me 121.

Then if I take 4 squared,
which is 16,
that adds up to 137.

So can we draw the Pythagorean
triangle for that?

It will look something
like this.

I've changed the scale of my
units here a little bit.

So we've got 11 there, 4 there,
and then this diagonal
is the square root of 137.
A nice Pythagorean prime.

BRADY HARAN: So just to be
absolutely clear, the

hypotenuse of a right-angle
triangle, when the other two

sides are integers, won't
be a Pythagorean prime?

LAURENCE EAVES: Its square root
is a Pythagorean prime.
BRADY HARAN: Its square root.
LAURENCE EAVES: Yeah.
MATT PARKER:That's 28.
How many arrows do you want?

So the next one, let's say we
did 3 to the power of, to the

power of, oh, arrow,
arrow, arrow.

Whatever you want
to call this.

JAMES GRIME: And that will give
you the third perfect
number for--
